bib.title: Understanding the drivers of deforestation and agricultural transformations in the Northwestern uplands of Cambodia
bib.author: Rada Kong and Jean-Christophe Diepart and Jean-Christophe Castella and Guillaume Lestrelin and Florent Tivet and Elisa Belmain and Agnès Bégué
bib.abstract: At the end of the 1990s, the Northwestern uplands of Cambodia were one of the last forest frontiers of the country. In a region that was the last Khmer Rouge stronghold, the opening of former conflict zones after a peace agreement initiated a vast movement of agricultural colonization. This movement was economically triggered by high market demand for agricultural commodities such as maize and cassava and fueled by a massive flow of spontaneous in-migration of land-poor farmers from lowland regions around the entire country. Focused on four upland districts along a pioneer front of Northwestern Cambodia, we analyzed historical trajectories of land use/cover changes using a chronological series of Landsat data from 1976 to 2016.
